content: The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees in the uniformed services or National Guard do not have their pay reduced while performing active service. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" guarantees that federal employees serving in the uniformed services or National Guard will not have their pay reduced during active duty. The "Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002" ensures that federal employees on active duty in the uniformed services or National Guard will receive an amount equal to their basic pay for the pay period, minus the pay and allowances received for that service. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 guarantees federal employees on active duty will receive an amount equal to their basic pay for the pay period, minus pay and allowances received for that service. Amounts under this section are payable for each pay period during which the employee is entitled to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 and does not otherwise receive basic pay. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures federal employees on active duty receive their basic pay minus any other pay received during that period. This applies when the employee is entitled to reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 and does not receive basic pay from their civilian employment. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 guarantees federal employees on active duty their basic pay minus any other pay received. Reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38 are determined without considering certain provisions and include specified reporting periods. Amounts payable to employees are to be paid by their employing agency from the appropriate fund. The Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002 ensures federal employees on active duty receive their basic pay from their employing agency, following regulations set by the Office of Personnel Management in consultation with the Secretary of Defense. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, will prescribe regulations for the Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002. Agency heads must establish procedures to ensure employee rights under this act, with specific instructions for the Federal Aviation Administration. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, in consultation with the Office of Personnel Management, will establish procedures to ensure employee rights under the Reservists and Guardsmen Pay Protection Act of 2002. The terms 'employee', 'Federal Government', and 'uniformed services' have specific meanings as defined in section 4303 of title 38. The term 'service in the uniformed services' is defined in section 4303 of title 38 and includes duty performed by National Guard members under section 502(f) of title 32. The term 'employing agency' refers to the agency or entity of the Government where an employee has reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. The term 'basic pay' includes any amount payable under section 5304. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 55 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. READY RESERVE-NATIONAL GUARD EMPLOYEE CREDIT ADDED TO GENERAL BUSINESS CREDIT. This section amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to add a new section related to business-related credits for Ready Reserve-National Guard employees. The effective date for amendments regarding pay periods beginning on or after September 11, 2001. SEC. 45G. READY RESERVE-NATIONAL GUARD EMPLOYEE CREDIT added to business-related credits in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under section 38 is 50% of the actual compensation amount for the taxable year. The actual compensation amount is the compensation paid when the employee is absent for qualified active duty. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit is limited to 12 months and does not apply on days when the employee was not scheduled to work for reasons other than qualified active duty. Qualified active duty refers to active duty excluding training duty specified in certain sections of the United States Code. The term 'compensation' is defined as any payment related to active duty, including training requirements for the Ready Reserve and National Guard drills, as well as hospitalization incident to such duty. The term 'compensation' refers to remuneration for employment that is deductible from gross income, and a Ready Reserve-National Guard employee is defined as a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard. The term 'National Guard' and 'Ready Reserve' are defined in relation to employees eligible for a tax credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code.
